text:
Testing v1.6 and getting the following warnings
```┌ Warning: Package CompilerSupportLibraries_jll does not have JLLWrappers in its dependencies:
│ - If you have CompilerSupportLibraries_jll checked out for development and have
│   added JLLWrappers as a dependency but haven't updated your primary
│   environment's manifest file, try `Pkg.resolve()`.
│ - Otherwise you may need to report an issue with CompilerSupportLibraries_jll
└ Loading JLLWrappers into CompilerSupportLibraries_jll from project dependency, future warnings for CompilerSupportLibraries_jll are suppressed.
┌ Warning: The call to compilecache failed to create a usable precompiled cache file for OpenSpecFun_jll [efe28fd5-8261-553b-a9e1-b2916fc3738e]
│   exception = Required dependency CompilerSupportLibraries_jll [e66e0078-7015-5450-92f7-15fbd957f2ae] failed to load from a cache file.```

text: I was able to fix it by just nuking all the artifacts, clones, packages, clones and installing everything fresh

elements.text: I was able to fix it by just nuking all the artifacts, clones, packages, clones and installing everything fresh

text: This can happen if you inherit a Manifest from v1.5.  Basically, just do a `pkg> resolve` or a `pkg> update` and things will be happier.

elements.text: This can happen if you inherit a Manifest from v1.5.  Basically, just do a
pkg> resolve
or a
pkg> update
and things will be happier.

text:
I ran into this issue as well (`"Package CompilerSupportLibraries_jll does not have JLLWrappers in its dependencies"`.

I’m finding that once the bad version of the package is in the 1.6 cache, it keeps on being reused, even in other projects.  Using `resolve` or `update` as <@U66GD0880> suggested doesn’t help.

Is there a good way to clean out the cache and/or otherwise clean this up after the fact?

text:
E.g., if when I create an empty project which only depends on `LsqFit.jl`, the following packages fail to precompile (they’ve already failed to precompile elsewhere):
```Precompiling project...

  ✗ MbedTLS_jll
  ✗ CompilerSupportLibraries_jll
  ✗ Zlib_jll```

text:
<@UDB26738Q> thanks for the cache location.  I can manually clean that out, but I’m wondering if there’s a nicer way?

I’m sure I’m not going to be the first person to run across this when upgrading from 1.5 to 1.6, so it would be nice to either prevent this, or at least have an easier way to clean it up (`Pkg.clear_cache([package_name])`?)

elements.text:

Pkg.clear_cache([package_name])

text: the cache is different between v1.5 and v1.6, how can they conflict?

text: I don’t think they are.   I had a local project with a Manifest.toml file generated on 1.5, and these packages failed to precompile when I ran `Pkg.instantiate`  on julia 1.6.

elements.text: I don’t think they are.   I had a local project with a Manifest.toml file generated on 1.5, and these packages failed to precompile when I ran
Pkg.instantiate
on julia 1.6.

text: oh, so the problem was the use of the manifest.  Note that manifests are very version-specific

elements.text: oh, so the problem was the use of the manifest.  Note that manifests are very version-specific

text: Yes, but there’s nothing stopping from Julia 1.6 from attempting to use a Manifest.toml file generated on Julia 1.5.

elements.text: Yes, but there’s nothing stopping from Julia 1.6 from attempting to use a Manifest.toml file generated on Julia 1.5.

text: Which is what happened here and which poisoned my cache, so to speak. :skull_and_crossbones:  :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Which is what happened here and which poisoned my cache, so to speak.

text: as a matter of fact, stdlibs change often from minor version to minor version, that makes instantiating a manifest built for a different minor version complicated

text: That’s fine.  It would be nice if there was something in the Manifest file indicating that it was generated by a different minor version of Julia, and which prevented it from being used.

elements.text: That’s fine.  It would be nice if there was something in the Manifest file indicating that it was generated by a different minor version of Julia, and which prevented it from being used.

text: I just bumped into this bug.  the issue is when `CompilerSupportLibraries_jll` is in the global manifest already, because maybe you used Julia v1.6 during development when JLLs weren't stdlibs yet

CompilerSupportLibraries_jll
is in the global manifest already, because maybe you used Julia v1.6 during development when JLLs weren't stdlibs yet
